title: The League Community's Reaction to Tyler 1's Ban Shows How Much it Needs to Grow.
body:
I usually don't comment much on these boards as I usually just come here to browse through in my leisure time, but seeing the Rioter's post on Tyler 1's ban and the reaction has me pretty concerned. The League of Legends board reaction to Tyler 1's ban has got to be one of the most depressing thing's I've seen coming from this community.  Tyler1's account should have been permabanned after his first 3 accounts were banned. The fact that he was as popular as he was on Twitch actually took me by surprise. Yeah, he may have played an pretty good Draven, but that is it.  Everybody flames and gets angry once in a while, but Tyler did it just about every game. Running down mid and flaming teammates constantly isn't entertaining; it's rude to his teammates and gives off a vibe to potentially new viewers who are interested in the game that it is okay to interact with other players that way. As league continues to become one of the biggest growing games among regular players and in competitive E-sports, people like Tyler 1 can't be around as a main attraction for people interested in League. He got what was eventually coming to him.


Edit: Guys, I get what you are saying about Tyler 1 maybe going down a bit in verbal abuse, but intentionally feeding is still a BAN WORTHY offense and he did it a lot; he even had a list he wrote down for people he would automatically troll if he saw them in his pre-game lobby.

Every. Single. Person. Strongly in favor of it will cite his past, and will have been ignorant to how he was actually playing now.  Not only that, but they will bypass logic and flat out insult anybody defending him.

The sad part is that people can be toxic as fuck and start witch hunts for somebody, and get no disciplinary action against them because of who they are.

I've become pretty concerned too about the people on the internet, and am saddened how people will just give the same toxic reply to this and just call me a toxic fan boy. 

What I'm upset about is the hypocrisy and ridiculous favoritism that is in play here

Much more so than people on here do. They heard about his behavior, went to see it, and was surprised that he wasn't toxic.

So you believe people here/reddit/etc.  have an un-bias opinion of his behavior?

I want you to think about what you said again.

A person who willingly donated money to him, had a good opinion of Tyler. What a shocker.

The guy had double digit perma-bans. If it were up to me, I would have sent the lifelong ban before it reached the number it had. Not just because his behavior was shitty enough to continuously receive bans, but because it would have been obvious that he never intended on stopping his shitty behavior.

I want you to think about your logic here.

There is a story, and a debate to be had. People have heard one side of the story about somebody being a terrible person, everybody keeps repeating this.

Some people are already a fan of his, they are loyal and bias.

Some people hate him because of things they hear about him, they stay away from him and parrot that he is a terrible person. They don't like him and are bias.

Some people decide to see the whole story, go to his stream, see that what people say about him isn't true, and come to their own conclusion that he's not the person reddit/boards says he is.


You then come along and tell me that the opinion's of the people who have seen the whole story are no longer valid, because they do not agree with yours.

Unless you're claiming almost all his previous perma-ban were done in error, my point and opinion still stands.

I'm unaware if he got sent chat logs for this new ban, nor do I care. That's on him to reveal if he wishes. But I've seen some clips where his behavior was completely out of line across several bans. At that point, I believed he should've received some sort of lifelong ban since it was clear that he didn't care about the standard perma-ban and was going to continue to create more account to be an ass in more games.

Does this mean a person is a horrible human being for their behavior in league? No. But it does mean I would rather him not be here if he's going to act in the ways that has him perma'ed so often.

I never paraded about to get Tyler banned, it's not my right to. But I also don't believe Riot should rescind this lifelong ban. His several perma-bans make it more than deserving in my eyes.

Yea there's that past justification that I was talking about. What I am upset about is how hypocritical riot has been, and how streamers are allowed to shit talk him all day with no action at all, and the fact that people act like there isn't a debate at all here and people who disagree are toxic trolls

It has been constantly established that other people's behavior is no excuse for your own. Tyler is not exempt from that rule.

And by "shit talk" Tyler, do you mean in game or through the stream? And if in-game, do these people get reported in enough game for poor behavior to get hit by the system?

The automatic system that continuously banned Tyler is completely un-bias. Yet it banned him constantly and not these other streamers.
Hah no. It was not about his reaction to his teammates. It was about him maturely avoiding drama with other streamers, who are allowed to start drama why? and then get perma banned now?
Tyler was not banned for his behavior outside the game, but for his behavior in-game.

This happens with literally every major decision that goes through league.

The content majority (Or, well, the larger portion of people) keep quiet and don't say anything because they're content. That or they start boasting and bragging to the other half.

The vocal minority fills the boards/reddits with posts about how Riot is in the wrong, how they're not right, etc. You can see it when Riot makes a change to the game too. 300 upvotes means nothing comparative to a 60+ million playerbase and a handful of people saying they dislike dynamic queue doesn't mean it's the entire community rallying against it. 

Agree or disagree, it's always the most upset that are the most vocal.

Anyways, I agree.

The only issue I have with the way Riot went about this was making a post about it and turning it into a spectacle. They should have just done it and moved on not even making a note of THEM DOING THEIR JOB.

Unfortunately, there's literally no other way to handle this.

1.) Tyler1 stops streaming, people get confused and start asking questions. Eventually he speaks out and causes a shitstorm.
2.) Tyler gets an e-mail, tells everyone about it, now people are asking Riot why and what he did, etc etc etc.

It's pretty obvious that no matter what you do. Especially when there are MANY people out there who are also causing problems.

So they decide to go about it in the least professional and most shitstorm creating way? By making a public spectacle out of it?

Like yes it's going to cause a hard/bad reaction, but literally any other decision then making a public spectacle of it THEMSELVES would have been better.

Uh, no.

The least professional way to deal with it (ESPECIALLY with someone who had as many viewers as Tyler1) is to do it in silence and maintain radio silence in hopes that it'd blow over. If you're going to do something major like ban a player indefinitely, you need to confront it and explain why because this is a major decision.
